title: How to detect "view not found error"
Memory growth with Node 10
Fix #3869: Add support for custom view cache key
body:
See description of the issue in https://github.com/expressjs/express/issues/3869.

*What this PR includes:*
- Add new option `cacheKey` to `renderOptions` of `render` method.
- Slightly refactor cache tests in `app.render.js`, add new ones for new `cacheKey` option.

For a better context, here is how it may be used in an engine https://github.com/pugjs/pug/pull/3099.

title: Views: custom cache key support
body:
This is probably not related directly to Express itself, but I think it's a nice feature to have and may cover some use cases. I refer specifically to Pug, but it may apply to any view engine.

# Use Case

A Pug user may want to use [filters](https://pugjs.org/language/filters.html) with dynamic content. But Pug compiles filters only once, they can't contain dynamic content. Express and Pug caches prevent to cache templates with a dynamic cache key, they use filename as a cache key instead. Most of the cache implementations support this, but Express and Pug don't, so you are unable to control how to cache templates.

*Some related discussions:*
https://github.com/pugjs/pug/issues/2603
https://github.com/pugjs/pug/issues/1782

# Suggested Solution

We can add the new option `cacheKey` to `render` method. And we can use it in `render` method to identify cached views. This is quite a small fix.

*Pros:*
- It's easy to implement and it won't be a breaking change.

*Cons:*
- It may complicate the API of the `render` method.
- It may require view engines to implement support for it. E.g. Pug has its own cache under the hood. But this should be very easy, just one line of code.

I'm going to submit PR for this one. Let me know your thoughts.

pass data to partial view and use it in every view/page
body:
Hi,
I am very new to nodejs-express. I am using ejs as engine. My problem is I have to use a partial view containing dynamic data in every page/view. I don't want to pass data from every router to render it. is it possible that I pass the data once and use it anywhere independent of the router. For example, in a navigation bar I am displaying user info with some notifications and I have to use this navbar allover my site. How can I achieve it without repassing the data.

title: How to use colon as normal character instead of route param
body:
Colon(:) used to define route param in Express/Koa.

```
app.get('/users/:userId/books/:bookId', function (req, res) {
  res.send(req.params)
})
```

Google API design use colon as custom verb
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1747852/51235171-ca8e4680-19a9-11e9-9397-dcfb7c083aba.png)

### Question: Is there a way to define a route in which I want use colon as normal character ?
Target: define a route that match `PUT /tasks/1234:undelete`, and define with string instead of regexp.

```
C:\Users\ThatTonybo\Desktop\discussion\node_modules\express\lib\application.js:214
  this.lazyrouter();
       ^

TypeError: Cannot read property 'lazyrouter' of undefined
    at use (C:\Users\ThatTonybo\Desktop\discussion\node_modules\express\lib\application.js:214:8)
```

Bug in rendering
body:
I don't know if this is an ejs or express issue, so sorry if i'm in the wrong place. But, here is my bug: I'm making an wiki for my game with blocks. I want to document every block and I do it like this: ```js router.get("/blocks/:block", (req, res) => { let block = req.params.block.toLowerCase(); if (!["grass", "dirt", "stone", "water", "log", "leaf"].includes(block)) return res.render("wiki/notFound.ejs", { user: req.user, session: req.session, title: "Wiki: Block not found", type: "specialBlock", block: block }); res.render(`wiki/blocks/${block}`, { user: req.user, session: req.session, title: `Wiki: ${block}` }); }); ``` It will send the user an error page when the block isn't one of the blocks in the array. Then, I use the variable `type` in my ejs like this: ```html <% if (!type) { %>

Sorry, that page is not found. Here are some reasons why:

<% } else if (type === "block") { %>

Sorry, you are on the wrong page.

<% } %> ``` When I go to the page while trying cross side scripting: (with after blocks/ ``) I get the error that `type` isn't defined: ``` ReferenceError: C:\Users\Paul_New\Desktop\nodejs\Websites\BlockGame-2D\views\wiki\notFound.ejs:13 11|

Wiki

>> 13| <% if (!type) { %> 14|

Sorry, that page is not found. Here are some reasons why:

Sorry, you are on the wrong page.

type is not defined ``` For questions, ask them. I think it has something todo with rendering html. But I don't know.

title: Unix Socket / NGINX / PM2 Cluster Mode
body:
I am trying to make Express connect to NGINX via Unix Sockets instead of TCP.
Running this code in cluster mode under pm2, causes each process to state that the process is already LISTENING and everything crashes.

Unix Socket Creation (app.js)
```
  var app_sock_dir = '/var/run/express/'
  app.server.listen(app_sock_dir + 'app.sock', ret => {
     require('fs').chmod(app_sock_dir + 'app.sock', 0777)
  })
```

pm2 cluster command, spawn 10 processes
`
pm2 start app.js -i 10
`

title: How to detect if the redirection is complete?
Documentation: router vs middleware
body:
Having recently read all the documentation under "Getting started" and "Guide" I've found that the concept of routing and middleware is somewhat ambigous.

The [Getting started -> Basic routing](https://expressjs.com/en/starter/basic-routing.html) page describes:

> Route definition takes the following structure:  
`app.METHOD(PATH, HANDLER)`

The [Guide -> Writing middleware](https://expressjs.com/en/guide/writing-middleware.html) guide explains exactly the same thing but now mentions it as:

> The following figure shows the **elements of a middleware function call**:

One gets the _feeling_ that a middleware is actually used with app.use() or router.use(). I am unsure how to improve the documentation as I, by reading this guides, did not get a clear definition of these concepts.

title: 404 for static files
Error middleware defaults status code to 200?
body: I noticed that when invoking error-handling middleware (via `next(err)`) and haven't explicitly set the response status code, it defaults to `200 OK`.  This strikes me as strange given it's purpose is to handle errors, so I was just curious if this is intentional and, if so, why?  Perhaps this should default to `5xx` instead?  Thanks for any insight!

title: Undocumented router workaround.
body:
Besides replacing `*` as `{0,}` in Express,
there is one more workaround should do with regex in router (in Express 4.x):

`.` (dot, period, which matches almost anything) should be replaced to `[\s\S]` in regex pattern, because dot in regex pattern will also be escaped.

Hope this can also be fixed in Express 5.

title: Can I use promises in my custom view engine?
What's the best way to pass information from one route to another?
body:
Hey there,

Basically, I'm using express in a REST API, and have been implementing a payment processor. The basic flow is something like this;
ROUTE: /payment
1. Client submits some data like the product information. Server receives and validates it against database. The server then calls the Payment Processor API and initialises the session with information like price, order number, etc... and then gets a "paymentSession". We then return this session to the client.
2. The client then do the payment, which then gets an encrypted payload from the payment processor. We then send this payload to another route on our server, `/payment/verify`, and here we can check if the payment was successful. If it was, we then want to grant the user permission to whatever it is they bought.

Here is where the problem comes in. The information I need in order to "grant the user permission" in the 2nd route, was created in the first route. Stuff like Order #, product information, etc...

What would be the best way for me to pass some data from the first endpoint to the second despite them being separate routes?

Thanks! Any help is appreciated. Let me know if more information is required!

title: Routing: slash character is captured as query string
body:
This follows an issue I had trying to reject some unwanted URLs of my routing: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/53663028/express-routing-matching-extra-url-tokens/53674664#53674664

TL;DR, it appears that the slash character is being processed by router.get() as belonging to the query string.

Example: with the regex /^\/(\d{1,})(?:$|\/([^\/]{0,})\/?$)/, for the path /1234/ForumTitle?page=2/test, we get req.query = {"page":"2/test"}.

Isn't it supposed to be a reserved character?

title: meta: express.js internals do not support Node.js 10+
body:
It seems that, when trying to get everything working in 10+, I found some Node.js behavior changes that have no work-arounds. I reported to Node.js core in https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/24585 and https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/24586 but there is no interest in fixing them. Until there is a fix, I would not recommend using Express.js on Node.js 10+

/cc @addaleax from Node.js core who was interested in seeing http/2 in Express, but now http/1 doesn't even work right

title: Update cookie-signature package
body:
A security bug was detected by the Shieldfy in the "cookie-signature" package.

Infected version: 1.0.6
description:-
Affected versions of `cookie-signature` are vulnerable to timing attacks as a result of using a fail-early comparison instead of a constant-time comparison. Timing attacks remove the exponential increase in entropy gained from increased secret length, by providing per-character feedback on the correctness of a guess via miniscule timing differences. Under favorable network conditions, an attacker can exploit this to guess the secret in no more than `charset*length` guesses, instead of `charset^length` guesses required were the timing attack not present.  

detected by Shieldfy Team 
shieldfy.io

title: After been nginx reverse proxy, configured to  /XXX
Strange behaviour between next('route') , next('router') and next('someString')
I cannot set cookie with domain localhost
Possible garbage collection issue on Node 10
default no-cache headers
body:
Hi there!

By default, express does not serve no-cache headers on routes, so for instance:

```
import * as express from 'express'

const app = express()
app.get('/', (_req, res) => {
  res.send('Hello')
})

app.listen(3000)
```

Results in the following:

```
curl -I localhost:3000
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
X-Powered-By: Express
Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8
Content-Length: 5
ETag: W/"5-9/+ei3uy4Jtwk1pdeF4MxdnQq/A"
Date: Thu, 15 Nov 2018 22:53:08 GMT
Connection: keep-alive
```

This is missing `Cache-Control: no-cache`, `Pragma: no-cahe` or `Expires: 0` headers that would inform the browser that the result of the request should not be cached.

My suggestion is to serve these files with no-cache headers by default, like [serve-static](https://expressjs.com/en/resources/middleware/serve-static.html). This will reduce the chance that folks will forget to configure it, and end up potentially having clients hang on to stale code.

(this is an issue I've recently run into on my project -- it seems that sometimes browsers do cache such responses when no cache headers are provided)

Thanks for your hard work!

title: How to rewrite url when using routers
Route.use with * ignore the last middleware
body:
The Problem:
Lets assume we have route '/A/:idOfA/B/:idOfB/C/:idOfC'
I want to add a route that handles every route that ends with `/someRoute`

I also added:
```javascript
router.param('idOfA', populateAParam);
router.param('idOfB', populateBParam);
router.param('idOfC', populateCParam);
```
To capture `/someRoute` for every possible route I added this:
`router.use(/.*\/someRoute/, someRouteHandler);`

The Expected Result:
The following functions should run in order:
populateAParam, populateBParam, populateCParam, someRouteHandler

The Actual Result:
The following functions are executed:
populateAParam, populateBParam, someRouteHandler

i.e. `populateCParam` was not executed

Any idea why is this happening? any better suggestion to accomplish this task?

title: Strict Routing
body:
I've been experimenting with strict routing using `express@latest` and have found that the following the requests all route to the same path when supplying `strict: true` to express. This doesn't seem to uphold the docs explanation of `Disabled by default, /foo and /foo/ are treated the same by the router.`.

```js
const express = require('express')
const app = express({ strict: true })
const port = 3022

app.get('/:param?/', (req, res) => res.json(req.params.param));

app.listen(port);
```

```
> curl -I http://localhost:3022/
HTTP/1.1 200 OK

> curl -I http://localhost:3022/abc
HTTP/1.1 200 OK

> curl -I http://localhost:3022/abc/
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
```

title: remove utils merge
Require parameter if a second parameter is included inside of a given array
body:
I was looking for a validator that requires a specific parameter if there's a parameter that equals to a specific value. Maybe something like this:

    const allowedsMethods = ['A', 'B'];

    ...

    check('method').custom(method => allowedMethods.includes(method))
    check('paramA').requireIfContains('method', ['A'])
    check('paramB').requireIfContains('method', ['A'])
    check('paramAorB').requireIfContains('method', ['A', 'B'])

- If `method` is contained inside `['A']`, then the property `paramA` will be required.
- If `method` is contained inside `['B']`, then the property `paramA` will be required.
- If `method` is contained inside `['A', 'B']`, then the property `paramA` will be required.

I was looking at the [currently available validators][1] and I didn't find something that would fit my needs. I tried to figure out how can I achieve this by using a custom validator, but I couldn't find any solution.


  [1]: https://github.com/chriso/validator.js
  [2]: https://express-validator.github.io/docs/custom-validators-sanitizers.html

title: Deployment to Production in centOS server
body:
Hi,

We are trying to deploy the expressjs app to the linux server. We have copied the project folder to the OS.We have installed node and npm also.
We have copied the node_modules(created by running npm i --production with in our local system and then copied the corresponding folder to the linux environment).

when we try to run node index.js command, we are getting below error:
```
Error: Cannot find module 'express'
    at Function.Module._resolveFilename (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:580:15)
    at Function.Module._load (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:506:25)
    at Module.require (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:636:17)
    at require (internal/modules/cjs/helpers.js:20:18)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/ctiapp/whistle/wbbe/index.js:1:77)
    at Module._compile (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:688:30)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:699:10)
    at Module.load (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:598:32)
    at tryModuleLoad (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:537:12)
    at Function.Module._load (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:529:3)
```
Someone please help us in deployment of expressjs app within linux server please.!

Thanks and Regards,
Kishore Kumar. K

title: Support graceful shutdown
body:
We're using a 3rd party package to do graceful shutdowns with express, so that when our application deploys, we can get exit code 0s, and not exit codes 127s from Docker finally giving up and killing the process (which looks like a container death in our metrics).

The code is pretty minimal:

https://github.com/moebius-mlm/http-graceful-shutdown/blob/master/src/graceful-shutdown-manager.ts

Seems like express should have a way for doing this directly.

title: Infinite cycle to timeout when sending POST request to GET endpoint
body:
Hi,
I have a GET endpoint and when I accidentally sent a POST request to that endpoint it took some time before timing out. After turning DEBUG on I noticed a pattern of repeated messages:

```
 express:router cookieParser  : /api/user +3ms  
 express:router jsonParser  : /api/user +2ms    
 express:router session  : /api/user +2ms       
 express:router helmet  : /api/user +2ms        
 express:router initialize  : /api/user +2ms    
 express:router authenticate  : /api/user +1ms  
 express:router <anonymous>  : /api/user +1ms   
 express:router serveStatic  : /api/user +2ms   
 express:router middleware  : /api/user +2ms    
 express:router dispatching POST /api/user +6ms 
 express:router query  : /api/user +1ms         
 express:router expressInit  : /api/user +2ms   
 express:router cookieParser  : /api/user +1ms  
 express:router jsonParser  : /api/user +2ms    
 express:router session  : /api/user +1ms       
 express:router helmet  : /api/user +3ms        
 express:router initialize  : /api/user +1ms    
 express:router authenticate  : /api/user +1ms  
 express:router <anonymous>  : /api/user +2ms   
 express:router serveStatic  : /api/user +1ms   
 express:router middleware  : /api/user +1ms    
 express:router dispatching POST /api/user +6ms 
 express:router query  : /api/user +1ms         
 express:router expressInit  : /api/user +2ms   
 express:router cookieParser  : /api/user +1ms  
 express:router jsonParser  : /api/user +2ms    
 express:router session  : /api/user +2ms       
 express:router helmet  : /api/user +2ms        
 express:router initialize  : /api/user +1ms    
 express:router authenticate  : /api/user +1ms  
 express:router <anonymous>  : /api/user +1ms   
 express:router serveStatic  : /api/user +2ms   
 express:router middleware  : /api/user +1ms    
 express:router dispatching POST /api/user +5ms 
 express:router query  : /api/user +2ms         
 express:router expressInit  : /api/user +1ms   
 express:router cookieParser  : /api/user +2ms  
 express:router jsonParser  : /api/user +2ms    
 express:router session  : /api/user +2ms       
 express:router helmet  : /api/user +1ms        
 ...
```
I have a catch all route and a route for serving static content and a proxy (it is a React application).
```
app.use(express.static(path.join(__dirname, "..", "build")));
const apiProxy = proxy("/", { target: "http://localhost:3000", ws: true });
app.use(apiProxy);
```
and
```
app.all("*", (req, res) => {
  res.status(404).send();
});
```
Is there a way how to prevent this behavior?
Thanks,
Karel

title: Changed count of arguments for custom error handler
Release 4.17
body:
This is a tracking issue for release 4.17.

**Please keep feature requests in their own issues**

If you want to make a comment on a particular change, please make the comment in the "Files changed" tab so comments are not lost during a rebase.

List of changes for release:
- [x] Add `express.raw` to parse raw bodies #3708
- [x] Add `express.text` to parse text bodies #3455
- [x] Improve error message for non-strings to `res.sendFile` #3582
- [x] Improve error message for `null`/`undefined` to `res.status` #2795 #2797 #3111
- [x] Support multiple hosts in `X-Forwarded-Host` #3494 #3495
- [x] Support Node.js 9.x #3617
- [x] Support Node.js 10.x #3656
- [x] Support Node.js 11.x
- [x] Support Node.js 12.x #3946
- [x] Upgrade `accepts` to 1.3.7 to bring in sorting fixes
- [x] Upgrade `body-parser` to 1.19.0 to bring in new encoding, `pb` shorthand, and url encoded parse fix
- [x] Upgrade `content-disposition` to 0.5.3
- [x] Upgrade `cookie` to 0.4.0 to add support for `SameSite=None` #3958
- [x] Upgrade `finalhandler` to 1.1.2 for stricter CSP header
- [x] Upgrade `parseurl` to 1.3.3
- [x] Upgrade `proxy-addr` to 2.0.5
- [x] Upgrade `qs` to 6.7.0 to bring in query parse fix
- [x] Upgrade `range-parser` to 1.2.1
- [x] Upgrade `send` to 0.17.1 to bring in stricter CSP and adjusted MIME types #3486
- [x] Upgrade `serve-static` to 1.14.1 to bring in `send` 0.17.1 changes
- [x] Upgrade `setprototypeof` to 1.1.1
- [x] Upgrade `statuses` to 1.5.0
- [x] Upgrade `type-is` to 1.6.18

**Testing this release**

If you want to try out this release, you can install it with the following commands:

``` bash
$ npm cache clean express
$ npm install expressjs/express#4.17
```

Owners/collaborators: please do not merge this PR :)

title: undefined: undefined added to http request headers if http.request used inside express
body: I am getting "HTTP message contains more than the configured limit of 64 headers" error when using request module to get the data from some third party urls. On debugging the issue, I got to know that there are some undefined undefined string added to http request headers due to which its length got increased. I seen the same issue reported earlier and mentioned that issue is in promisifyAll but I want to say that I am not using promisify at all then why I am getting this error.

body:
Added support for ppc64le arch for supported nodeJS versions. Please review.

Thanks!

title: req.route returns array, how to get active route?
body:
Hello, 
im trying to get the active route from req.route, (when array is returned)

### example:

 
```
app.get(['/index', '/product/:id'], function(req,res) { 
   console.log(req.route);
   res.json({error: false})
});
```

### expected output:
```
Route {
  path:
   [ '/index',
     '/product/:id'
 ],
  stack:
   [ Layer {
       handle: [Function],
       name: '<anonymous>',
       params: undefined,
       path: undefined,
       keys: [],
       regexp: /^\/?$/i,
       method: 'get' } ],
  methods: { get: true } }
```


how can i get the active route, 
if request url was: `/product/15` i want to know that the route is `/product/:id`
